Payments from multiple companies to Essential Consultants were first publicly alleged in an explosive report from lawyer Michael Avenatti, whose client, porn star Stormy Daniels, is suing Trump and Cohen to void a nondisclosure deal that bars her from discussing an alleged sexual encounter.

The company is linked to Viktor Vekselberg, a Russian oligarch has been sanctioned by the U.S.

"The claim that Viktor Vekselberg was involved in or provided any funding for Columbus Nova's engagement of Michael Cohen is patently untrue," Columbus Nova said.

The letters sent to the two corporations were led by Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., and signed by Sen. Richard Blumenthal, D-Conn.

Sen. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., sent his own questions to Novartis' CEO on May 11, and signed Warren and Blumenthal's letter to AT&T.

Cohen was also hired by investment management company Columbus Nova "as a business consultant regarding potential sources of capital and potential investments in real estate and other ventures," according a statement from the company.

Lawyers for Cohen said in a later court filing that Avenatti's report contained "numerous inaccurate statements," including attributing payments to Trump's lawyer that were actually sent to different people also named Michael Cohen.
Both letters say that the "unusual" series of payments to Cohen's company raise questions about a potential "pay-for-play operation" involving the companies and the Trump administration.
Avenatti pushed back on Twitter, saying Cohen's lawyers failed to address "99% of the statements in what we released."
Cohen created Essential Consultants in October 2016, shortly before he paid Daniels $130,000 as part of the agreement.
AT&T and Novartis did not immediately respond to CNBC's requests for comment on the Democrats' letters.
